v2.5/en/admin-settings/admin-settings.title: Authentication, Permissions and Global Configuration
v2.5/en/admin-settings/admin-settings.description: After installation, the system administrator should configure Rancher to configure authentication, authorization, security, default settings, security policies, drivers and global DNS entries.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/ad.title: Configuring Active Directory (AD)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/ad.description: If your organization uses Microsoft Active Directory as central user repository, you can configure Rancher to communicate with an Active Directory server to authenticate users. This allows Rancher admins to control access to clusters and projects based on users and groups managed externally in the Active Directory, while allowing end-users to authenticate with their AD credentials when logging in to the Rancher UI.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/au.title: Authentication
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/au.description: One of the key features that Rancher adds to Kubernetes is centralized user authentication. This feature allows your users to use one set of credentials to authenticate with any of your Kubernetes clusters.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/az.title: Configuring Azure AD
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/az.description: If you have an instance of Active Directory (AD) hosted in Azure, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their AD accounts. Configuration of Azure AD external authentication requires you to make configurations in both Azure and Rancher.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/fr.title: Configuring FreeIPA
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/fr.description: If your organization uses FreeIPA for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to login using their FreeIPA credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/gi.title: Configuring GitHub
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/gi.description: In environments using GitHub, you can configure Rancher to allow sign on using GitHub credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/go.title: Configuring Google OAuth
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/go.description: If your organization uses G Suite for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their G Suite credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/ke.title: Configuring Keycloak (SAML)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/ke.description: Create a Keycloak SAML client and configure Rancher to work with Keycloak. By the end your users will be able to sign into Rancher using their Keycloak logins

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/lo.title: Local Authentication
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/lo.description: Local authentication is the default until you configure an external authentication provider. Local authentication is where Rancher stores the user information, i.e. names and passwords, of who can log in to Rancher. By default, the admin user that logs in to Rancher for the first time is a local user.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/mi.title: Configuring Microsoft Active Directory Federation Service (SAML)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/mi.description: If your organization uses Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their AD FS credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/mi.title: 1. Configuring Microsoft AD FS for Rancher
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/mi.description: Before configuring Rancher to support AD FS users, you must add Rancher as a relying party trust in AD FS.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/mi.title: 2. Configuring Rancher for Microsoft AD FS
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/mi.description: After you complete Configuring Microsoft AD FS for Rancher, enter your AD FS information into Rancher to allow AD FS users to authenticate with Rancher.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/ok.title: Configuring Okta (SAML)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/ok.description: If your organization uses Okta Identity Provider (IdP) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their IdP credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/op.title: Configuring OpenLDAP
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/op.description: If your organization uses LDAP for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to communicate with an OpenLDAP server to authenticate users. This allows Rancher admins to control access to clusters and projects based on users and groups managed externally in the organisation's central user repository, while allowing end-users to authenticate with their LDAP credentials when logging in to the Rancher UI.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/op.title: OpenLDAP Configuration Reference
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/op.description: This section is intended to be used as a reference when setting up an OpenLDAP authentication provider in Rancher.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/pi.title: Configuring PingIdentity (SAML)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/pi.description: If your organization uses Ping Identity Provider (IdP) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in using their IdP credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/sh.title: Group Permissions with Shibboleth and OpenLDAP
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/sh.description: This page provides background information and context for Rancher users who intend to set up the Shibboleth authentication provider in Rancher.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/sh.title: Configuring Shibboleth (SAML)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/sh.description: If your organization uses Shibboleth Identity Provider (IdP) for user authentication, you can configure Rancher to allow your users to log in to Rancher using their Shibboleth credentials.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/us.title: Users and Groups
v2.5/en/admin-settings/authentication/us.description: Rancher relies on users and groups to determine who is allowed to log in to Rancher and which resources they can access. When you configure an external authentication provider, users from that provider will be able to log in to your Rancher server. When a user logs in, the authentication provider will supply your Rancher server with a list of groups to which the user belongs.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/config-private-re.title: Configuring a Global Default Private Registry
v2.5/en/admin-settings/config-private-re.description: You might want to use a private container registry to share your custom base images within your organization. With a private registry, you can keep a private, consistent, and centralized source of truth for the container images that are used in your clusters.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/drivers/cluster-d.title: Cluster Drivers
v2.5/en/admin-settings/drivers/cluster-d.description: Cluster drivers are used to create clusters in a hosted Kubernetes provider, such as Google GKE. The availability of which cluster driver to display when creating clusters is defined by the cluster driver's status. Only active cluster drivers will be displayed as an option for creating clusters. By default, Rancher is packaged with several existing cloud provider cluster drivers, but you can also add custom cluster drivers to Rancher.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/drivers/drivers.title: Provisioning Drivers
v2.5/en/admin-settings/drivers/drivers.description: Drivers in Rancher allow you to manage which providers can be used to deploy hosted Kubernetes clusters or nodes in an infrastructure provider to allow Rancher to deploy and manage Kubernetes.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/drivers/node-driv.title: Node Drivers
v2.5/en/admin-settings/drivers/node-driv.description: Node drivers are used to provision hosts, which Rancher uses to launch and manage Kubernetes clusters. A node driver is the same as a Docker Machine driver. The availability of which node driver to display when creating node templates is defined based on the node driver's status. Only active node drivers will be displayed as an option for creating node templates. By default, Rancher is packaged with many existing Docker Machine drivers, but you can also create custom node drivers to add to Rancher.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/k8s-metadata/k8s-.title: Upgrading Kubernetes without Upgrading Rancher
v2.5/en/admin-settings/k8s-metadata/k8s-.description: The RKE metadata feature allows you to provision clusters with new versions of Kubernetes as soon as they are released, without upgrading Rancher. This feature is useful for taking advantage of patch versions of Kubernetes, for example, if you want to upgrade to Kubernetes v1.14.7 when your Rancher server originally supported v1.14.6.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/pod-security-poli.title: Pod Security Policies
v2.5/en/admin-settings/pod-security-poli.description: Pod Security Policies (or PSPs) are objects that control security-sensitive aspects of pod specification (like root privileges).

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/cluster-proj.title: Cluster and Project Roles
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/cluster-proj.description: Cluster and project roles define user authorization inside a cluster or project. You can manage these roles from the Global > Security > Roles page.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/default-cust.title: Custom Roles
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/default-cust.description: Within Rancher, roles determine what actions a user can make within a cluster or project.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/global-permi.title: Global Permissions
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/global-permi.description: Permissions are individual access rights that you can assign when selecting a custom permission for a user.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/locked-roles.title: Locked Roles
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/locked-roles.description: You can set roles to a status of locked. Locking roles prevent them from being assigned users in the future.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/rbac.title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rbac/rbac.description: Within Rancher, each person authenticates as a user, which is a login that grants you access to Rancher. As mentioned in Authentication, users can either be local or external.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/app.title: Applying Templates
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/app.description: You can create a cluster from an RKE template that you created, or from a template that has been shared with you.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/cre.title: Creating and Revising Templates
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/cre.description: This section describes how to manage RKE templates and revisions. You an create, share, update, and delete templates from the Global view under Tools > RKE Templates.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/cre.title: Template Creator Permissions
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/cre.description: Administrators have the permission to create RKE templates, and only administrators can give that permission to other users.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/enf.title: Template Enforcement
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/enf.description: This section describes how template administrators can enforce templates in Rancher, restricting the ability of users to create clusters without a template.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/exa.title: Example Scenarios
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/exa.description: These example scenarios describe how an organization could use templates to standardize cluster creation.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/exa.title: Example YAML
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/exa.description: Below is an example RKE template configuration file for reference.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/ove.title: Overriding Template Settings
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/ove.description: When a user creates an RKE template, each setting in the template has a switch in the Rancher UI that indicates if users can override the setting. This switch marks those settings as Allow User Override.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke.title: RKE Templates
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke.description: RKE templates are designed to allow DevOps and security teams to standardize and simplify the creation of Kubernetes clusters.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke.title: RKE Templates and Infrastructure
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/rke.description: In Rancher, RKE templates are used to provision Kubernetes and define Rancher settings, while node templates are used to provision nodes.

v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/tem.title: Access and Sharing
v2.5/en/admin-settings/rke-templates/tem.description: If you are an RKE template owner, you can share it with users or groups of users, who can then use the template to create clusters.

v2.5/en/api/api-tokens/api-tokens.title: API Tokens
v2.5/en/api/api-tokens/api-tokens.description: By default, some cluster-level API tokens are generated with infinite time-to-live (ttl=0). In other words, API tokens with ttl=0 never expire unless you invalidate them. Tokens are not invalidated by changing a password.

v2.5/en/backups/back-up-rancher/back-up-.title: Backing up Rancher
v2.5/en/backups/back-up-rancher/back-up-.description: In this section, you'll learn how to back up Rancher running on any Kubernetes cluster. To backup Rancher installed with Docker, refer to the instructions for single node backups.

v2.5/en/backups/backups.title: Backups and Disaster Recovery
v2.5/en/backups/backups.description: In this section, you'll learn how to create backups of Rancher, how to restore Rancher from backup, and how to migrate Rancher to a new Kubernetes cluster.

v2.5/en/backups/configuration/backup-con.title: Backup Configuration
v2.5/en/backups/configuration/backup-con.description: The Backup Create page lets you configure a schedule, enable encryption and specify the storage location for your backups.

v2.5/en/backups/configuration/restore-co.title: Restore Configuration
v2.5/en/backups/configuration/restore-co.description: The Restore Create page lets you provide details of the backup to restore from

v2.5/en/backups/configuration/storage-co.title: Backup Storage Location Configuration
v2.5/en/backups/configuration/storage-co.description: Configure a storage location where all backups are saved by default. You will have the option to override this with each backup, but will be limited to using an S3-compatible object store.

v2.5/en/backups/docker-installs/docker-b.title: Backing up Rancher Installed with Docker
v2.5/en/backups/docker-installs/docker-b.description: After completing your Docker installation of Rancher, we recommend creating backups of it on a regular basis. Having a recent backup will let you recover quickly from an unexpected disaster.

v2.5/en/backups/docker-installs/docker-i.title: Backup and Restore for Rancher Installed with Docker

v2.5/en/backups/docker-installs/docker-r.title: Restoring Backups—Docker Installs
v2.5/en/backups/docker-installs/docker-r.description: If you encounter a disaster scenario, you can restore your Rancher Server to your most recent backup.

v2.5/en/backups/examples/examples.title: Examples
v2.5/en/backups/examples/examples.description: This section contains examples of Backup and Restore custom resources.

v2.5/en/backups/migrating-rancher/migrat.title: Migrating Rancher to a New Cluster
v2.5/en/backups/migrating-rancher/migrat.description: If you are migrating Rancher to a new Kubernetes cluster, you don't need to install Rancher on the new cluster first. If Rancher is restored to a new cluster with Rancher already installed, it can cause problems.

v2.5/en/backups/restoring-rancher/restor.title: Restoring Rancher
v2.5/en/backups/restoring-rancher/restor.description: A restore is performed by creating a Restore custom resource.

v2.5/en/best-practices/best-practices.title: Best Practices Guide
v2.5/en/best-practices/best-practices.description: The purpose of this section is to consolidate best practices for Rancher implementations. This also includes recommendations for related technologies, such as Kubernetes, Docker, containers, and more. The objective is to improve the outcome of a Rancher implementation using the operational experience of Rancher and its customers.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/c.title: Tips for Setting Up Containers
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/c.description: Running well-built containers can greatly impact the overall performance and security of your environment.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/l.title: Logging Best Practices
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/l.description: In this guide, we recommend best practices for cluster-level logging and application logging.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/m.title: Best Practices for Rancher Managed vSphere Clusters
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/m.description: This guide outlines a reference architecture for provisioning downstream Rancher clusters in a vSphere environment, in addition to standard vSphere best practices as documented by VMware.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/m.title: Monitoring Best Practices
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/m.description: Configuring sensible monitoring and alerting rules is vital for running any production workloads securely and reliably. This is not different when using Kubernetes and Rancher. Fortunately the integrated monitoring and alerting functionality makes this whole process a lot easier.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-managed/r.title: Best Practices for Rancher Managed Clusters

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/de.title: Rancher Deployment Strategy
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/de.description: There are two recommended deployment strategies for a Rancher server that manages downstream Kubernetes clusters. Each one has its own pros and cons. Read more about which one would fit best for your use case:

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/de.title: Tips for Running Rancher
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/de.description: This guide is geared toward use cases where Rancher is used to manage downstream Kubernetes clusters. The high-availability setup is intended to prevent losing access to downstream clusters if the Rancher server is not available.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/ra.title: Installing Rancher in a vSphere Environment
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/ra.description: This guide outlines a reference architecture for installing Rancher on an RKE Kubernetes cluster in a vSphere environment, in addition to standard vSphere best practices as documented by VMware.

v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/ra.title: Best Practices for the Rancher Server
v2.5/en/best-practices/rancher-server/ra.description: This guide contains our recommendations for running the Rancher server, and is intended to be used in situations in which Rancher manages downstream Kubernetes clusters.

v2.5/en/cis-scans/cis-scans.title: CIS Scans
v2.5/en/cis-scans/cis-scans.description: Rancher can run a security scan to check whether Kubernetes is deployed according to security best practices as defined in the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark.

v2.5/en/cis-scans/configuration/configur.title: Configuration
v2.5/en/cis-scans/configuration/configur.description: This configuration reference is intended to help you manage the custom resources created by the rancher-cis-benchmark application. These resources are used for performing CIS scans on a cluster, skipping tests, setting the test profile that will be used during a scan, and other customization.

v2.5/en/cis-scans/custom-benchmark/custo.title: Creating a Custom Benchmark Version for Running a Cluster Scan

v2.5/en/cis-scans/rbac/rbac.title: Roles-based Access Control
v2.5/en/cis-scans/rbac/rbac.description: This section describes the permissions required to use the rancher-cis-benchmark App.

v2.5/en/cis-scans/skipped-tests/skipped-.title: Skipped and Not Applicable Tests
v2.5/en/cis-scans/skipped-tests/skipped-.description: This section lists the tests that are skipped in the permissive test profile for RKE.

v2.5/en/cli/cli.title: CLI with Rancher
v2.5/en/cli/cli.description: Interact with Rancher using command line interface (CLI) tools from your workstation.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/backing-up-etcd/ba.title: Backing up a Cluster
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/backing-up-etcd/ba.description: In the Rancher UI, etcd backup and recovery for Rancher launched Kubernetes clusters can be easily performed.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/certificate-rotati.title: Certificate Rotation
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/certificate-rotati.description: Warning: Rotating Kubernetes certificates may result in your cluster being temporarily unavailable as components are restarted. For production environments, it's recommended to perform this action during a maintenance window.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cleaning-cluster-n.title: Removing Kubernetes Components from Nodes
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cleaning-cluster-n.description: Learn about cluster cleanup when removing nodes from your Rancher-launched Kubernetes cluster. What is removed, how to do it manually

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cloning-clusters/c.title: Cloning Clusters
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cloning-clusters/c.description: If you have a cluster in Rancher that you want to use as a template for creating similar clusters, you can use Rancher CLI to clone the cluster's configuration, edit it, and then use it to quickly launch the cloned cluster.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/ace.title: How the Authorized Cluster Endpoint Works
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/ace.description: This section describes how the kubectl CLI, the kubeconfig file, and the authorized cluster endpoint work together to allow you to access a downstream Kubernetes cluster directly, without authenticating through the Rancher server. It is intended to provide background information and context to the instructions for how to set up kubectl to directly access a cluster.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/clu.title: Cluster Access
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/clu.description: This section is about what tools can be used to access clusters managed by Rancher.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/clu.title: Adding Users to Clusters
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/clu.description: If you want to provide a user with access and permissions to all projects, nodes, and resources within a cluster, assign the user a cluster membership.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/kub.title: Access a Cluster with Kubectl and kubeconfig
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-access/kub.description: Learn how you can access and manage your Kubernetes clusters using kubectl with kubectl Shell or with kubectl CLI and kubeconfig file. A kubeconfig file is used to configure access to Kubernetes. When you create a cluster with Rancher, it automatically creates a kubeconfig for your cluster.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-admin.title: Cluster Administration
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-admin.description: After you provision a cluster in Rancher, you can begin using powerful Kubernetes features to deploy and scale your containerized applications in development, testing, or production environments.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler.title: Cluster Autoscaler with AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler.description: This guide will show you how to install and use Kubernetes cluster-autoscaler on Rancher custom clusters using AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler.title: Cluster Autoscaler
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autoscaler.description: In this section, you'll learn how to install and use the Kubernetes cluster-autoscaler on Rancher custom clusters using AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/e.title: Cluster Configuration
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/e.description: After you provision a Kubernetes cluster using Rancher, you can still edit options and settings for the cluster.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/r.title: RKE Cluster Configuration
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/r.description: In clusters launched by RKE, you can edit any of the remaining options that follow.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/s.title: Syncing
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/editing-clusters/s.description: Syncing is the feature for EKS and GKE clusters that causes Rancher to update the clusters' values so they are up to date with their corresponding cluster object in the hosted Kubernetes provider. This enables Rancher to not be the sole owner of a hosted cluster’s state. Its largest limitation is that processing an update from Rancher and another source at the same time or within 5 minutes of one finishing may cause the state from one source to completely overwrite the other.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/nodes/nodes.title: Nodes and Node Pools
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/nodes/nodes.description: After you launch a Kubernetes cluster in Rancher, you can manage individual nodes from the cluster's Node tab. Depending on the option used to provision the cluster, there are different node options available.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/pod-security-polic.title: Adding a Pod Security Policy
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/pod-security-polic.description: Prerequisite: The options below are available only for clusters that are launched using RKE.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/restoring-etcd/res.title: Restoring a Cluster from Backup
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/restoring-etcd/res.description: etcd backup and recovery for Rancher launched Kubernetes clusters can be easily performed. Snapshots of the etcd database are taken and saved either locally onto the etcd nodes or to a S3 compatible target. The advantages of configuring S3 is that if all etcd nodes are lost, your snapshot is saved remotely and can be used to restore the cluster.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/tools/tools.title: Tools for Logging, Monitoring, and Visibility
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/tools/tools.description: Rancher contains a variety of tools that aren't included in Kubernetes to assist in your DevOps operations. Rancher can integrate with external services to help your clusters run more efficiently. Tools are divided into following categories:

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/upgrading-kubernet.description: Following an upgrade to the latest version of Rancher, downstream Kubernetes clusters can be upgraded to use the latest supported version of Kubernetes.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.title: Setting up Existing Storage
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: This section describes how to set up existing persistent storage for workloads in Rancher.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.title: Using an External Ceph Driver
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: These instructions are about using the external Ceph driver in an RKE2 cluster. If you are using RKE, additional steps are required. For details, refer to this section.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.title: Provisioning Storage Examples
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: Rancher supports persistent storage with a variety of volume plugins. However, before you use any of these plugins to bind persistent storage to your workloads, you have to configure the storage itself, whether its a cloud-based solution from a service-provider or an on-prem solution that you manage yourself.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.title: NFS Storage
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: Before you can use the NFS storage volume plug-in with Rancher deployments, you need to provision an NFS server.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.title: vSphere Storage
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: To provide stateful workloads with vSphere storage, we recommend creating a vSphereVolume StorageClass. This practice dynamically provisions vSphere storage when workloads request volumes through a persistent volume claim.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: A persistent volume (PV) is a piece of storage in the Kubernetes cluster, while a persistent volume claim (PVC) is a request for storage.

v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.title: iSCSI Volumes
v2.5/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-storag.description: In Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters that store data on iSCSI volumes, you may experience an issue where kubelets fail to automatically connect with iSCSI volumes. This failure is likely due to an incompatibility issue involving the iSCSI initiator tool. You can resolve this issue by installing the iSCSI initiator tool on each of your cluster nodes.

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/cluster-pro.title: Setting up Kubernetes Clusters in Rancher

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Creating an Aliyun ACK Cluster
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Alibaba Cloud Kubernetes (ACK). Rancher has already implemented and packaged the cluster driver for ACK, but by default, this cluster driver is inactive. In order to launch ACK clusters, you will need to enable the ACK cluster driver. After enabling the cluster driver, you can start provisioning ACK clusters.

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Creating an AKS Cluster
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Microsoft Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS).

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Creating a Huawei CCE Cluster
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Huawei Cloud Container Engine (CCE). Rancher has already implemented and packaged the cluster driver for CCE, but by default, this cluster driver is inactive. In order to launch CCE clusters, you will need to enable the CCE cluster driver. After enabling the cluster driver, you can start provisioning CCE clusters.

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Creating an EKS Cluster
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: Amazon EKS provides a managed control plane for your Kubernetes cluster. Amazon EKS runs the Kubernetes control plane instances across multiple Availability Zones to ensure high availability. Rancher provides an intuitive user interface for managing and deploying the Kubernetes clusters you run in Amazon EKS. With this guide, you will use Rancher to quickly and easily launch an Amazon EKS Kubernetes cluster in your AWS account. For more information on Amazon EKS, see this documentation.

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Minimum EKS Permissions
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: Documented here is a minimum set of permissions necessary to use all functionality of the EKS driver in Rancher. Additional permissions are required for Rancher to provision the Service Role and VPC resources. Optionally these resources can be created before the cluster creation and will be selectable when defining the cluster configuration.

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Setting up Clusters from Hosted Kubernetes Providers
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: In this scenario, Rancher does not provision Kubernetes because it is installed by providers such as Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE), Amazon Elastic Container Service for Kubernetes, or Azure Kubernetes Service.

v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.title: Creating a Tencent TKE Cluster
v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted-kube.description: You can use Rancher to create a cluster hosted in Tencent Kubernetes Engine (TKE). Rancher has already implemented and packaged the cluster driver for TKE, but by default, this cluster driver is inactive. In order to launch TKE clusters, you will need to enable the TKE cluster driver. After enabling the cluster driver, you can start provisioning TKE clusters.

v2.5/en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/arc.title: Architecture
v2.5/en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/arc.description: Fleet can manage deployments from git of raw Kubernetes YAML, Helm charts, or Kustomize or any combination of the three. Regardless of the source, all resources are dynamically turned into Helm charts, and Helm is used as the engine to deploy everything in the cluster. This gives you a high degree of control, consistency, and auditability. Fleet focuses not only on the ability to scale, but to give one a high degree of control and visibility to exactly what is installed on the cluster.

v2.5/en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/win.title: Windows Support
v2.5/en/deploy-across-clusters/fleet/win.description: Prior to Rancher v2.5.6, the agent did not have native Windows manifests on downstream clusters with Windows nodes. This would result in a failing agent pod for the cluster.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.description: The documents in this section contain resources for less common use cases.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.title: Enabling the API Audit Log to Record System Events
v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.description: You can enable the API audit log to record the sequence of system events initiated by individual users. You can know what happened, when it happened, who initiated it, and what cluster it affected. When you enable this feature, all requests to the Rancher API and all responses from it are written to a log.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.title: Tuning etcd for Large Installations
v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.description: When running larger Rancher installations with 15 or more clusters it is recommended to increase the default keyspace for etcd from the default 2GB. The maximum setting is 8GB and the host should have enough RAM to keep the entire dataset in memory. When increasing this value you should also increase the size of the host. The keyspace size can also be adjusted in smaller installations if you anticipate a high rate of change of pods during the garbage collection interval.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.title: Opening Ports with firewalld
v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.description: We recommend disabling firewalld. For Kubernetes 1.19.x and higher, firewalld must be turned off.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.title: Docker Install with TLS Termination at Layer-7 NGINX Load Balancer
v2.5/en/installation/resources/advanced/.description: For development and testing environments that have a special requirement to terminate TLS/SSL at a load balancer instead of your Rancher Server container, deploy Rancher and configure a load balancer to work with it conjunction.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/choosing-.title: Choosing a Rancher Version
v2.5/en/installation/resources/choosing-.description: This section describes how to choose a Rancher version.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/custom-ca.title: About Custom CA Root Certificates
v2.5/en/installation/resources/custom-ca.description: If you're using Rancher in an internal production environment where you aren't exposing apps publicly, use a certificate from a private certificate authority (CA).

v2.5/en/installation/resources/feature-f.title: Allow Unsupported Storage Drivers
v2.5/en/installation/resources/feature-f.description: This feature allows you to use types for storage providers and provisioners that are not enabled by default.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/feature-f.title: Enabling Experimental Features
v2.5/en/installation/resources/feature-f.description: Rancher includes some features that are experimental and disabled by default. You might want to enable these features, for example, if you decide that the benefits of using an unsupported storage type outweighs the risk of using an untested feature. Feature flags were introduced to allow you to try these features that are not enabled by default.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/feature-f.title: UI for Istio Virtual Services and Destination Rules
v2.5/en/installation/resources/feature-f.description: This feature enables a UI that lets you create, read, update and delete virtual services and destination rules, which are traffic management features of Istio.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/helm-vers.title: Helm Version Requirements
v2.5/en/installation/resources/helm-vers.description: This section contains the requirements for Helm, which is the tool used to install Rancher on a high-availability Kubernetes cluster.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Setting up a High-availability RKE Kubernetes Cluster
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: This section describes how to install a Kubernetes cluster. This cluster should be dedicated to run only the Rancher server.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Setting up a High-availability RKE2 Kubernetes Cluster for Rancher
Setting up a High-availability K3s Kubernetes Cluster for Rancher

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: About High-availability Installations
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: We recommend using Helm, a Kubernetes package manager, to install Rancher on a dedicated Kubernetes cluster. This is called a high-availability Kubernetes installation because increased availability is achieved by running Rancher on multiple nodes.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Setting up Nodes in Amazon EC2
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: In this tutorial, you will learn one way to set up Linux nodes for the Rancher management server. These nodes will fulfill the node requirements for OS, Docker, hardware, and networking.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: This tutorial is intended to help you provision the underlying infrastructure for a Rancher management server.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Set up Infrastructure for a High Availability RKE Kubernetes Cluster
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: This tutorial is intended to help you create a high-availability RKE cluster that can be used to install a Rancher server.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Set up Infrastructure for a High Availability RKE2 Kubernetes Cluster
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: This tutorial is intended to help you provision the underlying infrastructure for a Rancher management server.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Setting up an NGINX Load Balancer
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: NGINX will be configured as Layer 4 load balancer (TCP) that forwards connections to one of your Rancher nodes.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.title: Setting up Amazon ELB Network Load Balancer
v2.5/en/installation/resources/k8s-tutor.description: This how-to guide describes how to set up a Network Load Balancer (NLB) in Amazon's EC2 service that will direct traffic to multiple instances on EC2.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/local-sys.description: The System Charts repository contains all the catalog items required for features such as monitoring, logging, alerting and global DNS.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/tls-secre.description: Kubernetes will create all the objects and services for Rancher, but it will not become available until we populate the tls-rancher-ingress secret in the cattle-system namespace with the certificate and key.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/tls-setti.title: TLS Settings
v2.5/en/installation/resources/tls-setti.description: Changing the default TLS settings depends on the chosen installation method.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/troublesh.title: Troubleshooting the Rancher Server Kubernetes Cluster
v2.5/en/installation/resources/troublesh.description: This section describes how to troubleshoot an installation of Rancher on a Kubernetes cluster.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/update-ra.description: Follow these steps to update the SSL certificate of the ingress in a Rancher high availability Kubernetes installation or to switch from the default self-signed certificate to a custom certificate.

v2.5/en/installation/resources/upgrading.description: Rancher uses cert-manager to automatically generate and renew TLS certificates for HA deployments of Rancher. v2.5/en/introduction.title: Rancher 2.5
v2.5/en/introduction.description: Rancher adds significant value on top of Kubernetes: managing hundreds of clusters from one interface, centralizing RBAC, enabling monitoring and alerting. Read more.

v2.5/en/istio/configuration-reference/ca.title: Additional Steps for Project Network Isolation

v2.5/en/istio/configuration-reference/en.description: If you have restrictive Pod Security Policies enabled, then Istio may not be able to function correctly, because it needs certain permissions in order to install itself and manage pod infrastructure. In this section, we will configure a cluster with PSPs enabled for an Istio install, and also set up the Istio CNI plugin.

v2.5/en/istio/disabling-istio/disabling-.title: Disabling Istio
v2.5/en/istio/disabling-istio/disabling-.description: This section describes how to uninstall Istio in a cluster or disable a namespace, or workload.

v2.5/en/istio/istio.title: Istio
v2.5/en/istio/istio.description: Istio is an open-source tool that makes it easier for DevOps teams to observe, secure, control, and troubleshoot the traffic within a complex network of microservices.

v2.5/en/istio/rbac/rbac.title: Role-based Access Control
v2.5/en/istio/rbac/rbac.description: This section describes the permissions required to access Istio features.

v2.5/en/istio/resources/resources.description: This section describes the minimum recommended computing resources for the Istio components in a cluster.

v2.5/en/istio/setup/deploy-workloads/dep.description: Prerequisite: To enable Istio for a workload, the cluster and namespace must have the Istio app installed.

v2.5/en/istio/setup/enable-istio-in-name.title: 2. Enable Istio in a Namespace
v2.5/en/istio/setup/enable-istio-in-name.description: You will need to manually enable Istio in each namespace that you want to be tracked or controlled by Istio. When Istio is enabled in a namespace, the Envoy sidecar proxy will be automatically injected into all new workloads that are deployed in the namespace.

v2.5/en/istio/setup/gateway/gateway.description: The gateway to each cluster can have its own port or load balancer, which is unrelated to a service mesh. By default, each Rancher-provisioned cluster has one NGINX ingress controller allowing traffic into the cluster.

v2.5/en/istio/setup/set-up-traffic-manag.title: 5. Set up Istio's Components for Traffic Management
v2.5/en/istio/setup/set-up-traffic-manag.description: A central advantage of traffic management in Istio is that it allows dynamic request routing. Some common applications for dynamic request routing include canary deployments and blue/green deployments. The two key resources in Istio traffic management are virtual services and destination rules.

v2.5/en/istio/setup/setup.title: Setup Guide
v2.5/en/istio/setup/setup.description: This section describes how to enable Istio and start using it in your projects.

v2.5/en/istio/setup/view-traffic/view-tr.description: This section describes how to view the traffic that is being managed by Istio.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/certificates/cert.description: Learn how to add an SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) certificate or TLS (Transport Layer Security) certificate to either a project, a namespace, or both, so that you can add it to deployments

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/configmaps/config.title: ConfigMaps
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/configmaps/config.description: While most types of Kubernetes secrets store sensitive information, ConfigMaps store general configuration information, such as a group of config files. Because ConfigMaps don't store sensitive information, they can be updated automatically, and therefore don't require their containers to be restarted following update (unlike most secret types, which require manual updates and a container restart to take effect).

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.title: The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.description: Learn about the horizontal pod autoscaler (HPA). How to manage HPAs and how to test them with a service deployment

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.title: Background Information on HPAs
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.description: The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) is a Kubernetes feature that allows you to configure your cluster to automatically scale the services it's running up or down. This section provides explanation on how HPA works with Kubernetes.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.title: Managing HPAs with kubectl
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.description: This section describes HPA management with kubectl. This document has instructions for how to:

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.title: Managing HPAs with the Rancher UI
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.description: The Rancher UI supports creating, managing, and deleting HPAs. You can configure CPU or memory usage as the metric that the HPA uses to scale.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.title: Testing HPAs with kubectl
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/horitzontal-pod-a.description: This document describes how to check the status of your HPAs after scaling them up or down with your load testing tool. For information on how to check the status from the Rancher UI (at least version 2.3.x), refer to Managing HPAs with the Rancher UI.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/k8s-in-rancher.title: Kubernetes Resources
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/k8s-in-rancher.description: The Cluster Explorer is a new feature in Rancher v2.5 that allows you to view and manipulate all of the custom resources and CRDs in a Kubernetes cluster from the Rancher UI. This section will be updated to reflect the way that Kubernetes resources are handled in Rancher v2.5.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/load-balancers-an.title: Adding Ingresses to Your Project
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/load-balancers-an.description: Ingresses can be added for workloads to provide load balancing, SSL termination and host/path-based routing. Learn how to add Rancher ingress to your project

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/load-balancers-an.description: Kubernetes supports load balancing in two ways: Layer-4 Load Balancing and Layer-7 Load Balancing. Learn about the support for each way in different deployments

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/registries/regist.description: Learn about the Docker registry and Kubernetes registry, their use cases and how to use a private registry with the Rancher UI

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/secrets/secrets.description: Secrets store sensitive data like passwords, tokens, or keys. They may contain one or more key value pairs.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/add-a-s.description: A sidecar is a container that extends or enhances the main container in a pod. The main container and the sidecar share a pod, and therefore share the same network space and storage. You can add sidecars to existing workloads by using the Add a Sidecar option.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/deploy-.title: Deploying Workloads
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/deploy-.description: Read this step by step guide for deploying workloads. Deploy a workload to run an application in one or more containers.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/rollbac.description: Sometimes there is a need to rollback to the previous version of the application, either for debugging purposes or because an upgrade did not go as planned.

v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/upgrade.title: Upgrading Workloads
v2.5/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/upgrade.description: When a new version of an application image is released on Docker Hub, you can upgrade any workloads running a previous version of the application to the new one.

v2.5/en/logging/logging.description: Rancher integrates with popular logging services. Learn the requirements and benefits of integrating with logging services, and enable logging on your cluster.

v2.5/en/logging/migrating/migrating.description: Starting in v2.5, the logging feature available within Rancher has been completely overhauled. The logging operator from Banzai Cloud has been adopted; Rancher configures this tooling for use when deploying logging.

v2.5/en/logging/rbac/rbac.description: Rancher logging has two roles, logging-admin and logging-view.

v2.5/en/logging/taints-tolerations/taint.description: "Tainting" a Kubernetes node causes pods to repel running on that node.

v2.5/en/longhorn/longhorn.description: Longhorn is a lightweight, reliable and easy-to-use distributed block storage system for Kubernetes.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/configuratio.description: It is usually not necessary to directly edit the Prometheus custom resource because the monitoring application automatically updates it based on changes to ServiceMonitors and PodMonitors.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/configuratio.description: A PrometheusRule defines a group of Prometheus alerting and/or recording rules.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/configuratio.description: The route configuration is the section of the Alertmanager custom resource that controls how the alerts fired by Prometheus are grouped and filtered before they reach the receiver.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/configuratio.description: ServiceMonitors and PodMonitors are both pseudo-CRDs that map the scrape configuration of the Prometheus custom resource.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/memor.description: Every time series in Prometheus is uniquely identified by its metric name and optional key-value pairs called labels.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/migra.title: Migrating to Rancher v2.5 Monitoring
v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/migra.description: If you previously enabled Monitoring, Alerting, or Notifiers in Rancher before v2.5, there is no automatic upgrade path for switching to the new monitoring/alerting solution. Before deploying the new monitoring solution via Cluster Explore, you will need to disable and remove all existing custom alerts, notifiers and monitoring installations for the whole cluster and in all projects.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/monit.description: - Display CPU and Memory Metrics for a Workload

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/persi.description: To allow the Grafana dashboard to persist after the Grafana instance restarts, add the dashboard configuration JSON into a ConfigMap. ConfigMaps also allow the dashboards to be deployed with a GitOps or CD based approach. This allows the dashboard to be put under version control.

v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/unins.title: Uninstall Monitoring
v2.5/en/monitoring-alerting/guides/unins.description: 1. From the Cluster Explorer, click Apps & Marketplace.

v2.5/en/opa-gatekeper/opa-gatekeper.title: OPA Gatekeeper
v2.5/en/opa-gatekeper/opa-gatekeper.description: To ensure consistency and compliance, every organization needs the ability to define and enforce policies in its environment in an automated way. OPA (Open Policy Agent) is a policy engine that facilitates policy-based control for cloud native environments. Rancher provides the ability to enable OPA Gatekeeper in Kubernetes clusters, and also installs a couple of built-in policy definitions, which are also called constraint templates.

v2.5/en/overview/architecture-recommenda.title: Architecture Recommendations
v2.5/en/overview/architecture-recommenda.description: Kubernetes cluster. If you are installing Rancher on a single node, the main architecture recommendation that applies to your installation is that the node running Rancher should be separate from downstream clusters.

v2.5/en/overview/architecture/architectu.title: Architecture
v2.5/en/overview/architecture/architectu.description: This section focuses on the Rancher server, its components, and how Rancher communicates with downstream Kubernetes clusters.

v2.5/en/overview/concepts/concepts.title: Kubernetes Concepts

v2.5/en/overview/overview.title: Overview
v2.5/en/overview/overview.description: Rancher is a container management platform built for organizations that deploy containers in production. Rancher makes it easy to run Kubernetes everywhere, meet IT requirements, and empower DevOps teams.

v2.5/en/pipelines/concepts/concepts.description: The purpose of this page is to explain common concepts and terminology related to pipelines.

v2.5/en/pipelines/config/config.title: Pipeline Configuration Reference
v2.5/en/pipelines/config/config.description: In this section, you'll learn how to configure pipelines.

v2.5/en/pipelines/example-repos/example-.title: Example Repositories
v2.5/en/pipelines/example-repos/example-.description: Rancher ships with several example repositories that you can use to familiarize yourself with pipelines. We recommend configuring and testing the example repository that most resembles your environment before using pipelines with your own repositories in a production environment. Use this example repository as a sandbox for repo configuration, build demonstration, etc. Rancher includes example repositories for:

v2.5/en/pipelines/example/example.title: Example YAML File
v2.5/en/pipelines/example/example.description: Pipelines can be configured either through the UI or using a yaml file in the repository, i.e. .rancher-pipeline.yml or .rancher-pipeline.yaml.

v2.5/en/pipelines/pipelines.title: Pipelines
v2.5/en/pipelines/pipelines.description: As of Rancher v2.5, Git-based deployment pipelines are now deprecated. We recommend handling pipelines with Rancher Continuous Delivery powered by Fleet, available in Cluster Explorer.

v2.5/en/pipelines/storage/storage.title: Configuring Persistent Data for Pipeline Components
v2.5/en/pipelines/storage/storage.description: The pipelines' internal Docker registry and the Minio workloads use ephemeral volumes by default. This default storage works out-of-the-box and makes testing easy, but you lose the build images and build logs if the node running the Docker Registry or Minio fails. In most cases this is fine. If you want build images and logs to survive node failures, you can configure the Docker Registry and Minio to use persistent volumes.

v2.5/en/project-admin/namespaces/namespa.title: Namespaces
v2.5/en/project-admin/namespaces/namespa.description: Within Rancher, you can further divide projects into different namespaces, which are virtual clusters within a project backed by a physical cluster. Should you require another level of organization beyond projects and the default namespace, you can use multiple namespaces to isolate applications and resources.

v2.5/en/project-admin/pipelines/pipeline.title: Rancher's CI/CD Pipelines
v2.5/en/project-admin/pipelines/pipeline.description: Use Rancher’s CI/CD pipeline to automatically checkout code, run builds or scripts, publish Docker images, and deploy software to users

v2.5/en/project-admin/pod-security-polic.title: Pod Security Policies
v2.5/en/project-admin/pod-security-polic.description: These cluster options are only available for clusters in which Rancher has launched Kubernetes.

v2.5/en/project-admin/project-admin.title: Project Administration
v2.5/en/project-admin/project-admin.description: Projects are objects introduced in Rancher that help organize namespaces in your Kubernetes cluster. You can use projects to create multi-tenant clusters, which allows a group of users to share the same underlying resources without interacting with each other's applications.

v2.5/en/project-admin/project-members/pr.title: Adding Users to Projects
v2.5/en/project-admin/project-members/pr.description: If you want to provide a user with access and permissions to specific projects and resources within a cluster, assign the user a project membership.

v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/ov.title: Setting Container Default Resource Limits
v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/ov.description: When setting resource quotas, if you set anything related to CPU or Memory (i.e. limits or reservations) on a project / namespace, all containers will require a respective CPU or Memory field set during creation. See the Kubernetes documentation for more details on why this is required.

v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/ov.title: Overriding the Default Limit for a Namespace
v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/ov.description: Although the Namespace Default Limit propagates from the project to each namespace when created, in some cases, you may need to increase (or decrease) the quotas for a specific namespace. In this situation, you can override the default limits by editing the namespace.

v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/qu.title: Resource Quota Type Reference
v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/qu.description: When you create a resource quota, you are configuring the pool of resources available to the project. You can set the following resource limits for the following resource types.

v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/qu.title: How Resource Quotas Work in Rancher Projects
v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/qu.description: Resource quotas in Rancher include the same functionality as the native version of Kubernetes. However, in Rancher, resource quotas have been extended so that you can apply them to projects.

v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/re.title: Project Resource Quotas
v2.5/en/project-admin/resource-quotas/re.description: In situations where several teams share a cluster, one team may overconsume the resources available: CPU, memory, storage, services, Kubernetes objects like pods or secrets, and so on.  To prevent this overconsumption, you can apply a resource quota, which is a Rancher feature that limits the resources available to a project or namespace.

v2.5/en/project-admin/tools/tools.title: Tools for Logging, Monitoring, and Visibility
v2.5/en/project-admin/tools/tools.description: Rancher contains a variety of tools that aren't included in Kubernetes to assist in your DevOps operations. Rancher can integrate with external services to help your clusters run more efficiently. Tools are divided into following categories:

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/ama.description: Read this step by step Rancher AWS guide to quickly deploy a Rancher server with a single-node downstream Kubernetes cluster attached.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/dep.title: Deploying Rancher Server
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/dep.description: Use one of the following guides to deploy and provision Rancher and a Kubernetes cluster in the provider of your choice.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/dig.title: Rancher DigitalOcean Quick Start Guide
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/dig.description: Read this step by step Rancher DigitalOcean guide to quickly deploy a Rancher server with a single-node downstream Kubernetes cluster attached.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/goo.title: Rancher GCP Quick Start Guide
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/goo.description: Read this step by step Rancher GCP guide to quickly deploy a Rancher server with a single-node downstream Kubernetes cluster attached.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/mic.title: Rancher Azure Quick Start Guide
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/mic.description: Read this step by step Rancher Azure guide to quickly deploy a Rancher server with a single-node downstream Kubernetes cluster attached.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/qui.title: Manual Quick Start
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/qui.description: Howdy Partner! This tutorial walks you through:

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/qui.title: Vagrant Quick Start
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/deployment/qui.description: The following steps quickly deploy a Rancher Server with a single node cluster attached.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/quick-start-gu.title: Rancher Deployment Quick Start Guides
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/quick-start-gu.description: Note: The intent of these guides is to quickly launch a sandbox that you can use to evaluate Rancher. These guides are not intended for production environments. For comprehensive setup instructions, see Installation.

v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/workload/workl.title: Deploying Workloads
v2.5/en/quick-start-guide/workload/workl.description: These guides walk you through the deployment of an application, including how to expose the application for use outside of the cluster.

v2.5/en/security/cve/cve.title: Security Advisories and CVEs
v2.5/en/security/cve/cve.description: Rancher is committed to informing the community of security issues in our products. Rancher will publish security advisories and CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) for issues we have resolved. New security advisories are also published in Rancher's GitHub security page.

v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.5-benchma.title: CIS 1.5 Benchmark - Self-Assessment Guide - Rancher v2.5
v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.5-benchma.description: CIS v1.5 Kubernetes Benchmark - Rancher v2.5 with Kubernetes v1.15

v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.5-hardeni.title: Hardening Guide with CIS 1.5 Benchmark
v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.5-hardeni.description: This document provides prescriptive guidance for hardening a production installation of a RKE cluster to be used with Rancher v2.5. It outlines the configurations and controls required to address Kubernetes benchmark controls from the Center for Information Security (CIS).

v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.6-benchma.title: CIS 1.6 Benchmark - Self-Assessment Guide - Rancher v2.5.4
v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.6-benchma.description: CIS 1.6 Kubernetes Benchmark - Rancher v2.5.4 with Kubernetes v1.18

v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.6-hardeni.title: Hardening Guide with CIS 1.6 Benchmark
v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/1.6-hardeni.description: This document provides prescriptive guidance for hardening a production installation of a RKE cluster to be used with Rancher v2.5.4. It outlines the configurations and controls required to address Kubernetes benchmark controls from the Center for Information Security (CIS).

v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/rancher-2.5.title: Self-Assessment and Hardening Guides for Rancher v2.5
v2.5/en/security/rancher-2.5/rancher-2.5.description: Rancher v2.5 introduced the capability to deploy Rancher on any Kubernetes cluster. For that reason, we now provide separate security hardening guides for Rancher deployments on each of Rancher's Kubernetes distributions.

v2.5/en/security/security-scan/security-.title: Security Scans
v2.5/en/security/security-scan/security-.description: The documentation about CIS security scans has moved here.

v2.5/en/system-tools/system-tools.description: System Tools is a tool to perform operational tasks on Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters or installations of Rancher on an RKE cluster. The tasks include:

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/dns/dns.title: DNS
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/dns/dns.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check name resolution issues in your cluster.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/imported-cluster.title: Registered clusters
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/imported-cluster.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check clusters that you are registering or that are registered in Rancher.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.title: Troubleshooting Controlplane Nodes
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.description: This section applies to nodes with the controlplane role.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.title: Troubleshooting etcd Nodes
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.description: This section contains commands and tips for troubleshooting nodes with the etcd role.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.title: Kubernetes Components
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.description: The commands and steps listed in this section apply to the core Kubernetes components on Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.title: Troubleshooting nginx-proxy
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.description: The nginx-proxy container is deployed on every node that does not have the controlplane role. It provides access to all the nodes with the controlplane role by dynamically generating the NGINX configuration based on available nodes with the controlplane role.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.title: Troubleshooting Worker Nodes and Generic Components
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-compo.description: This section applies to every node as it includes components that run on nodes with any role.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-resou.title: Kubernetes resources
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/kubernetes-resou.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check the most important Kubernetes resources and apply to Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/logging/logging.title: Logging
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/logging/logging.description: The following log levels are used in Rancher:

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/networking/netwo.title: Networking
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/networking/netwo.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check networking related issues in your cluster.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/rancherha/ranche.title: Rancher HA
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/rancherha/ranche.description: The commands/steps listed on this page can be used to check your Rancher Kubernetes Installation.

v2.5/en/troubleshooting/troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
v2.5/en/troubleshooting/troubleshooting.description: This section contains information to help you troubleshoot issues when using Rancher.

v2.5/en/user-settings/cloud-credentials/.title: Managing Cloud Credentials
v2.5/en/user-settings/cloud-credentials/.description: When you create a cluster hosted by an infrastructure provider, node templates are used to provision the cluster nodes. These templates use Docker Machine configuration options to define an operating system image and settings/parameters for the node.

v2.5/en/user-settings/node-templates/nod.title: Managing Node Templates
v2.5/en/user-settings/node-templates/nod.description: When you provision a cluster hosted by an infrastructure provider, node templates are used to provision the cluster nodes. These templates use Docker Machine configuration options to define an operating system image and settings/parameters for the node. You can create node templates in two contexts:

v2.5/en/user-settings/preferences/prefer.title: User Preferences
v2.5/en/user-settings/preferences/prefer.description: Each user can choose preferences to personalize their Rancher experience. To change preference settings, open the User Settings menu and then select Preferences.

v2.5/en/user-settings/user-settings.title: User Settings
v2.5/en/user-settings/user-settings.description: Within Rancher, each user has a number of settings associated with their login: personal preferences, API keys, etc. You can configure these settings by choosing from the User Settings menu. You can open this menu by clicking your avatar, located within the main menu.
